question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned to identify various species of flora and fauna from the places that we visited. Throughout this course, we learned to identify 150+ species. Additionally, we learned about the local indigenous cultures and traditions. We also learned about the history of places that we went such as Australia as a penal colony.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the skill of writing notes in the field, plant and animal identification, biogeography knowledge, ecology knowledge and insight into native culture. We learned about inter connectivity of ecosystems and how humans are involved in it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the ability to identify so many different flora and fauna of Australia, including very primitive plants. I gained a new perspective on Australian culture and politics, particularly with Indigenous peoples as the traditional custodians of the land. I also took thorough field notes throughout the class, which increased my absorption of the content and enriched my learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Being able to see, hear and then write about the flora and fauna we learned about allowed me to organize eveything in the brain, providing me a more enriching course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Glass and Dr. Lauer made this course incredibly engaging. During our outdoor activities such as hikes, they would point out prevalent species of plants and animals and talk about processes involved in that environment. We had a quiz for each leg of the trip and review sessions. Dr. Glass and Dr. Lauer were always open to and encouraged asking of questions. We also got to hear from a range of perspectives from our various guides. I particularly enjoyed the Kakadu camping expedition, Sydney tours, and activities at Cape Tribulation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The field notebooks, hands on learning, hiking and fish surveys all facilitated learning. Our professors were able to use lectures in addition to in the field exploration.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Alex Glass and Nancy Lauer were positively wonderful professors. They are knowledgeable, always open to questions, approachable, and deeply passionate. I was especially inspired by the depth of Dr. Glass's fascination and delight when discussing geology on the top of a beautiful mountain or at the side of a highway by a 1.9-million-year-old cutout. The course was a great balance between experiential learning and more traditional/academic learning (lectures, videos, quizzes) covering topics like native plants and animals.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class integrated deep learning into every place that we visited and ensured interdisciplinary learning in all of our studies. For instance, at our hike at Ubirr rock, we learned about indigenous culture and sacred sites through the rock paintings, learned about the specific geology of these rocks, and learned about the wildlife that inhabits the area like the rock wallaby and the St Andrews cross spider. We were able to integrate all of these topics in one day to make the class integrative and intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: On-field learning, quick memorization skills, and identification skills. I also learned about the differences between ecosystems and how these differences lead to varied species.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. My favorite, and in my opinion, most important area of knowledge that I received was regarding the history of Australia, its colonization, and the existence and cultural contexts of the aboriginal peoples that were first here. To fully understand and appreciate an area, a foundation of historical analysis must be first established. I strongly enjoyed learning about many of the holistic purposes of the land, how it was affected after/during colonization, and why Australia is the way it now is. It encouraged me to consider the causes and effects of human impact. 
2. I appreciated the hands-on teaching of this course. Specifically, days in which we were able to observe marine life (such as the Bondi Beach walk, Great Barrier Reef snorkel, etc.). It allowed me to fully get a grasp on my environment 
3. I have never used a field notebook in the way I have before this class. I believe that the use of a notebook and having to actively write in it while doing activities forced me to be much more attentive and engaged. I'm also thankful I have it for future reference, as it quite literally is an accumulation of everything I did/saw/learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use a hand lens, a snorkel, and a field notebook. I got better at being an auditory learner. I learned to respect and listen to different perspectives, both of the local culture and amongst my class group. I learned how to identify species and how adaptations respond to the climate. I gained a greater understanding of how geology can shape speciation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - lots of species identifications- crossbedding!- plant strategies

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Perhaps the most valuable thing I learned during this course is to keenly observe the environment around me at all times. From spotting various unexpected plants during hikes, to thinking critically about the geological characteristics of a site, to looking out of the bus window and seeing a new animals species, I learned to always keep my eyes and ears open, even when I'm not in an allotted class activity. Secondly, I learned about basic classification for animals and plants, including Phylums and Subphylums, as well as plant reproductive strategies. Lastly, I learned how to travel and take care of myself in a foreign country by using public transport, shopping for groceries, and finding my way around unfamiliar cities. These skills will stick with me for life, far beyond the scopes of this course, and I am very excited to return to the United States feeling much more independent and knowledgeable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to identify lots of plants and animals, about the history of Australian culture and Aboriginal culture, and the geology of Australia. Both Alex Glass and Jen Glass were extremely knowledgable, being able to recall so many facts about everything that we saw (and we saw a lot). They seemed genuinely excited about the topics they were teaching, and they loved to answer all the questions we had. There was so much information that we learned through our many guides and tours, with so much information in our field notebooks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to retain information in the field- having the ability to actively take notes during a field.
2. I learned in-depth knowledge of the surrounding plants and animals
3. I learned about the perspective of aboriginal people that helped me interpret information from various points of view.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Much of the skills that I developed during the course involved gaining confidence and independence in another country. The majority of them have been assigned to finding restaurants and making meals. Throughout the program, my confidence grew and developed, and the meals were difficult to adventure through the cities alone and manage my time effectively. Another skill that I developed was studying with limited wifi. Some of the locations had minimal wifi, so it was important to be able to study effectively using my notebook, which, while a challenge at first, ended up being extremely beneficial in terms of my memorization and deeper understanding. Finally, my way of thinking about geology shifted. Being able to see geological concepts in person instead of a textbook allowed for better conceptualization and understanding. This also applied to the many organisms that we saw.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I didn't know anything about Biology and Geology before this course and so now I see rocks and plants in an entirely different way. 
1. I learned how to identify the minerals in rocks and determine how they formed
2. I learned how plant classifications work and why it is important to use the scientific name
3. I learned how to identify leaves based on the attributes such as sclerophyll and conifers

Glass facilitated thoughtful conversations and was patient with group questions and explained them in a way that was fairly simple to understand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Grading was very clear. The balance of both on your own time assignments and in class quizzes was the perfect structure for our on the go style class. I appreciated that the majority of in class instruction was out in the field, and that the formal class setting was more of a review

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: - The professor was very knowledgable and passionate about geology. I liked having my field notebook always. The review sessions were helpful and the test format was good.Jen the TA: Jen was a powerful presence on this trip. From providing care for hurting students to being kind to bugs, she set an example of what it means to be there for all beings. Her resilience is inspiring. I wish she was given more space by Alex to share her academic knowledge.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor, Dr. Alex Glass, and the TA, Jen Glass, both enthusiastically answered questions, taught us new lessons about biology, geology, and science in general, and maintained positive attitudes throughout the trip. I'm very grateful to both of them for their patience and kindness, and I think that both Alex and Jen encouraged students to be curious beyond the scope of grades and academics, which is an incredibly valuable life skill. I would definitely keep the tours led by Alex and Jen, and I think the lecture style of students writing down what the instructors say in field notebooks prepared students for real-life scientific study. Alex and Jen worked incredibly well together, and stayed calm in situations of stress and exhaustion that naturally come during a monthlong program full of activities. I especially noticed that Jen payed close attention to the mental and physical health of all students, and was always the first to offer to accompany a student to a health facility, check on students who seem to be unwell, and ensure that all students are fed, healthy, and happy. Both the instructor and the TA made this course fun, safe, and intellectually challenging, and I believe they have done a fantastic job with this program.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The group aspect of this course was great, with many interesting activities in our schedule. Both the instructor Dr. Alexander Glass and TA Jen Glass were amazing and they worked very well together, creating an experience where we learned a lot while also being able to enjoy the beautiful landscapes of Australia. I enjoyed being constantly going from place to place, exploring as much as we could in the month together. The occasional review sessions reenforced our learning and prepared us for the quizzes throughout the course. I really enjoyed learning in the field instead of being in a classroom. Alex and Jen also managed the logistics very well, removing the stress of traveling in a foreign country.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Glass and Jen Glass (TA) were the greatest facilitators of learning in the class. Based off of the extent of their knowledge and general excitement for learning, they were the reason we were excited to learn about everything around us. Having consistent quizzes was actually a good check to our knowledge. Having constant lectures in the middle of our adventures was very beneficial given that everything he lectured about we could see or touch. I found my retention of information to be much higher that it is at school.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Much of the class is interest-based learning, with leading questions that can deepen one's understanding of biology, Geology, and other subjects. Alex led many of the tours, which were fast-paced and covered a myriad of topics, allowing the students to gain a lot of information over a short period of time. The outdoor nature of the course is a must, and it was amazing to see the stuff we were talking about not on a screen but in real life in front of my eyes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He gave a lot of hiking tours in which we could see plants and rocks along the hike. That was a majority of the class. Also being able to see animals at different types of preserves and wildlife zoos. I would like to keep the fish surveys and snorkelling because I have never done anything like that before. I also loved the Danitree rainforest and any sort of hike on a beach where we could see coconuts, coral skeletons and shells.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the review sessions because they were very helpful in reviewing all the content we covered between quizzes, especially because there was a lot of content covered. The overall learning environment of the class was excellent. The instructor did a great job at facilitating my learning because of the interactive structure of the course. Being able to be so involved and connected to what I was learning made it easier to retain information.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was both mentally and physically stimulating! We were constantly learning new things, so not only were we taking lots of notes and having once-in-a-lifetime experiences, but we also did a huge amount of hiking and other physical activities that left us exhausted (in a good way!) at the end of the day.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We usually live our lives as If things that surround us have always been like they are. However, this class makes you think about the slow change that's led to the current natural conditions and how things were millenia ago. This opens the debate about how things are changing now and how humans are influencing it

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Being outside in nature made it stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The experiential learning, traveling around Australia, and seeing all types of creatures was so intellectually and spiritually stimulating. I feel like a new person after this experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We were always in the field seeing animals, plants and geological formations in person. I couldn’t see how it could be any more stimulating, it was fantastic

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Dr. Glass' passion for the taught material, along with the experience of seeing the Australian continent in person made the course one of the most intellectually stimulating I have ever had.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was so stimulating because it was almost entirely field based, outdoor learning is infinitely better than learning through a screen.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Taking daily hikes and tours around the country kept me very involved in the course, however it could sometimes be overwhelming and we often would not have a lot of free time to explore the area on our own.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: A large component of the intellectual stimulation I received from this class was due to a preexisting foundation of knowledge that was formed by the lectures/quizzes that were due before the activity. It allowed me to recall on something I had already learned, which peaked my interest.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: LOVED HOW EVERYDAY WAS A FIELD TRIP!!! YAYAYAYY. Everyone in the group was really enthusiastic about learning and asked lots of questions. Alex would answer questions in great depth! Also he would point out everything that we should take a closer look at. There were some amazing sights I saw with my hand lens

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: identifying the plants around you was an awesome way to learn from and about the landI would have loved more of an aboriginal perspective on history/ botany/ land stewardship throughout the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Just about everything in this class was intellectually stimulating and exciting. Our style of learning was hands-on, literally - we touched leaves, bark, insects, and even animals - and I think this learning style enabled students of all styles of learning to gain knowledge from the course. Furthermore, I loved the discussion-style reviews hosted by the instructors at each location. These sessions facilitated conversation and pondering beyond the scopes of the information covered by the course, and encouraged students to read through their notes and think critically about what they understood and where they might need clarification. Additionally, both Alex (the instructor) and Jen (the TA) brought a wide range of background knowledge to the program, and taught us important about biological and geological processes that are not part of the syllabus but nonetheless incredibly valuable scientific skills. I enjoyed every single day of the program because each day was a new adventure and a chance to gain interesting knowledge to carry with me for the rest of my life.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Traveling between all the different locations showcases so much of Australia's diverse landscape. We were able to cram so many exciting activities in our schedule. Seeing the animals and plants that we were being quizzed on was very cool. We were able to see almost everything that we learned about, up close in person. Everything was timed great, such as seeing the mangroves in low tide, going on night hikes to see creatures that only come out at night, overall the schedule was planned very well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was incredibly intellectually stimulating because we were going so many places. Having constantly new environments actually made learning better because we could focus on specific species and ask questions about exactly what we see or hear. This has been the most exciting and effective learning environment I've been a part of.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was very stimulating due to the environment. The class being physically in Australia made all the activities interesting and important to the class materials as a whole.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It would be fun to learn more about contemporary Australian culture.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class so intellectually stimulating was the interactive structure of the course. We didn't learn species from pictures in a textbook, we learned them from hiking through the Australia and seeing the plants in their natural environments, we learned about the fish by swimming in lakes and and the Great Barrier Reef and seeing the species swimming below us, and about the animals by going to see them in person. We learned about the history of Australia by going to the locations where that history happened and we learned about the history and practices of the Aboriginal people by talking to them and reading about their stories. Being able to interact with the people, places, and things I learned about on this trip gave much more meaning to everything I learned and made it easier to retain the information because I now had a connection to this information and it became a part of my experiences and my memories.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is awesome! I 100% recommend it, because every day we are doing something that I will remember for the rest of my life. It is very physically exhausting, although it is not super difficult (but still moderately difficult) in the academic quiz portions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The best option if you want a field experience. Australia has a lot to offer, and no, animals won't kill you, just follow the professor's instructions always. Good luck!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to hike and move your body.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: For sure take it. The class parts are pretty easy, especially if you get close with your group and study together (use Quizlet and Slides for species quizzes). It is a life changing experience and you will hopefully make amazing memories.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them it’s the best class I’ve ever taken and the coolest experience of my life. Professor Glass is a bank of knowledge and his TA Jen was as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you love nature and animals, and want to experience one of the most unique environments in the modern world, come on this trip!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I absolutely 100% recommend this course as long as you are willing to be outside and hiking, snorkeling, and traveling for a month. There is no class that could beat this one in its immersive qualities.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure that you are okay with being really active, staying outdoors, living with others, and spending a lot time on your own and with others in the program.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! It requires constant energy and is not for those who enjoy leisurely time only. It is also for those who enjoy being in large groups and participating together. Be ready for all weather types, constant travel, and plenty of group bonding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be ready to learn as soon as the plane wheels touch the ground. You will learn as much from your fellow students and tour guides as from the prof. Have curiosity endurance and appreciate this wonderful experience you are fortunate to have.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say to embrace your curiosity and ask questions! This program is a once-in-a-lifetime experience where I felt child-like wonder and appreciation for the beauty of our natural world just about every day, so enjoy each and every moment. Also, the students and instructors of this course are all friendly, open to questions, and caring, so enjoy fun adventures and excursions with your peers throughout the trip.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely take this course, Alex Glass is the man. It's also Australia which is so cool. I think this program is unique in that we do everything in the field and that we're together much more than other study abroad programs. There are definitely some early mornings and some later nights, but this is great for anyone that loves to travel, anyone that loves the outdoors, and anyone who wants to explore something new.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get excited!!! If you love the outdoors, long walks, exploring new cities, and nature, PLEASE take this class!!! This was my favorite Duke experience and I could not recommend this enough. The sheer number of species learned is incredibly rewarding and the connection to nature from the class is unlike anything else.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As long as you have a pulse and are curious, this is the course for you. All you need is an interest in biology or geology. As an arachnophobe, everyone was accepting and helpful, especially during the spider hike. The class is very collaborative and the students want to see each other do well. Australia has been an amazing experience and I recommend the course to any student who is interested.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class will round out your perception of the job sphere. Not everything is about just making money and going into engineering, econ, or CS, or med school like Duke often perpetuates. The humanities and the theoretical and natural sciences have so much value.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course to any student, especially if they consider themselves outdoorsy. This course changed the way I noticed things around me, the way I look at the plants and animals I see and the way I think about our place in the world (in terms of geology and the long lasting memory of the Aboriginal people). The memories I made and the experiences I have are so unique to this trip. Memories of exploring a foreign country with new friends, hiking the Blue Mountains and going down thousands of steps with breathtaking views, petting wallabies and feeding crocodiles and snorkeling in the Great Barrier Reef. I would recommend this course because when else are you going to be able to travel across the country and learn about its history, its people, and the life that inhabits its.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout the Earth Science course, I, as a learner, developed a comprehensive understanding of various geological processes and phenomena. One of the key insights I gained pertains to the intricate interplay between Earth's internal forces and external influences, shaping the planet's dynamic features. This involved delving into the mechanics of plate tectonics, seismic activity, and volcanic processes, allowing me to appreciate the profound impact these forces have on the Earth's surface. Additionally, I honed my skills in interpreting and analyzing geological data, such as maps, cross-sections, and rock formations. This enhanced my ability to decipher the Earth's history and provided practical knowledge applicable to real-world scenarios, like identifying potential natural hazards or understanding the formation of valuable resources. Lastly, the course fostered a systems thinking approach, encouraging me to view the Earth as a complex, interconnected system where changes in one component can have cascading effects on the entire planet. This holistic perspective is invaluable for addressing contemporary environmental challenges and underscores the importance of responsible stewardship of our planet.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In reflecting on the overall learning environment of this Earth Science class, I found that the instructor played a pivotal role in facilitating my learning. Their enthusiasm for the subject matter and interactive teaching style created an engaging atmosphere that made complex concepts more accessible. The incorporation of real-world examples and practical applications helped me grasp abstract ideas, fostering a deeper understanding of Earth Science principles. Additionally, the course structure, with a balanced mix of lectures, hands-on activities, and collaborative projects, provided a well-rounded learning experience. The inclusion of multimedia resources, such as interactive simulations and virtual field trips, enhanced my comprehension and made the content more vivid and memorable. The consistent feedback and constructive assessments also contributed to my academic growth. Looking ahead, I would definitely advocate for maintaining the interactive teaching methods, practical applications, and diverse learning resources as integral components of the course, as they were instrumental in enriching my understanding of Earth Science concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking the Earth Science course in the future. Personally, I found it to be an incredibly enriching and eye-opening experience. This course comprehensively explores the Earth's dynamic processes, ranging from the intricate details of geological formations to the broader understanding of climatic patterns and environmental interactions. Throughout the semester, I gained a profound appreciation for the interconnectedness of Earth's systems and the impact of human activities on our planet. The engaging lectures, hands-on experiments, and field trips allowed me to apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations, enhancing my understanding of Earth's complexity. The course deepened my knowledge of natural phenomena and fostered a sense of environmental responsibility. If you are interested in understanding the world around you and the critical issues facing our planet, this Earth Science course is undoubtedly a rewarding and intellectually stimulating choice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about many environmental and climate concepts, such as geostrophic balance, the formation of a hurricanes, and the concepts behind El Nino (ENSO).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about some of the factors controlling ocean and atmospheric circulations, the variations that occur in these cycles over time, and some of the fundamentals of how to model their behavior.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Global energy budget and how to quantify short wave and long wave radiation in the atmosphere
2. Geostrophic balance is a force balance between pressure gradient force and Coriolis force (application of Navier Stokes equation)
3. How to interpret various graphs and identify trends of temperature, pressure, depth, etc. for the atmosphere and the ocean

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Coriolis force
-interaction between the atmosphere and the ocean
-impact of ocean ice on ocean properties
-circulation in the air and the ocean

response_text: This class teaches you to identify the mechanisms that govern ocean and atmospheric circulation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the theories of the origin of life is distinct from the theory of evolution, I learned a lot about how the fossil record, despite its biases, can provide a really essential insight into evolution because there are some things that simply cannot be gathered from studying extant species (like understanding that limbs/tetrapods evolved for fully aquatic life), and I learned that evolution/the phylogenetic tree isn’t necessarily a process of progress or becoming more intelligent/advanced, because natural processes cull the tree of life, including via mass extinctions, and sexual and natural selection doesn’t necessarily privilege the smartest or ‘fittest’ per se, just those with the greatest ability to reproduce.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I loved the content and teaching I just really think the class suffered from a general lack of engagement. I would also consider having three tests instead of two because I think the first test had a little too much material covered and splitting the course into three exams instead of two may also keep students more engaged. I would also even say that if students are treating the class like a blow off and not attending, just fail them. The content is so interesting and Prof. Glass has so much to say, but having a disinterested class that barely attends, never asks questions, doesn’t participate, etc really does harm the overall learning environment. Also, I hope Prof. Glass teaches the class on macro-evolutionary trends in the fossil record in the future!! Even if just a few highly interested students take it I feel like it is still worth it! question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The focus of this class was on teaching the theory and concepts of climate science, and helped introduce a whole new world of knowledge to us. I liked how the course was structured - each chapter focused on one aspect of the climate system (atmosphere, hydrosphere, etc) and went into a good level of depth without subjecting us to the physics and chemistry of it. Specifically, this class helped me build a good enough level of knowledge of each aspect of the climate system to a point that I can now understand the jargon and concepts - and thus broadly understand scientific papers or discussions on the subject. 
Concepts that struck me:
1. Aerosols can help reduce global warming (in some cases)! Now I finally understand the discussions on geoengineering
2. The science of coral bleaching and the importance of the ocean system in balancing our climate.
3. How complex it all actually is! I knew that it was but this course helped me understand why.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. The five homework assignments were often quite challenging, which helped us think critically about the course content. 
2. I also really enjoyed doing the project, which gave us the opportunity to apply the scientific theory that we learnt in class to a topic of our interest. 
3. I also really really appreciated that the professor began each class by doing a recap of what we had learnt previously on that topic. This helped immensely in retaining all the dense and complex material that we were learning.
4. I liked how the professor linked many of the scientific concepts and processes of the climate system to discussions on how they would be impacted with global warming. As a climate policy researcher, these discussions were very interesting and important for me and helped me feel like the reason I took this class was fulfilled.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This has been one of my favorite courses! question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was a very informative course about all things water pollution. I would definitely recommend this course to anyone but it may be helpful to have a little bit of a scientific background.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was extremely effective in providing an overview of pollution sources in freshwater and ocean environments. I felt like the course was also effective in providing an understanding of how these pollutants interact with the environment. Not just telling us what the pollutants were, but also understanding their environmental impacts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned so much about different types of pollution and I really wish we had more time to learn more. I was really excited to learn about invasive species but the course went too fast!
2. I learned to read and think critically. Nicolas gave us enough relevant information to effectively assess the proposal of a method (e.g., deep water pumping).
3. I also actually was able to refresh some of the concepts I previously learned in limnology and stream ecology (e.g., Redfield ratio) and to learn how to determine the response of the ecosystem to changes in nutrient source.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the complexities of freshwater and ocean pollution. Many topics we discussed I had heard about generally. It was interesting getting the scientific background of each process, implementation strategies, cost analysis of implementation, and developing a critical eye for further environmental damage.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a non-environmental major, almost everything I learned in the class was new to me! I think understanding that not all new solutions (even if proposed by renowned scholars) work and have clear fundamentals gaps, such as the deep ocean water pumping. I also found that understanding the multi-scale impacts of different pollutants very interesting, such as how one pollutant can really only affect larger species (entanglement) OR it could affect from the microbiome and work its way through biomagnification to the top of the food web. Furthermore, I found that as an engineer, we are always wanting to problem solve, but sometimes, as in the case with BP spill - the best method is to do nothing at all and that engineered solutions may exacerbate the issue (dispersants).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I loved the learning environment that Nicolas and Perrin created. Things to keep:
1. Lecture is not always a lecture. It is something to facilitate class discussion. The fact that any student can chime in to ask question is great.
2. I loved that the class did not require a paper. It is helpful to do one, but grad classes are heavy and discussions usually serve the purpose of learning.
3. I loved that we got to present on our own interested pollution issue and invite the author to speak to the class. I have never done that before.
4. I loved that the class was small so I was comfortable speaking up.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor held the class like an open discussion, where he lectured, but at any point we could ask questions and he clarified. There were minimal HW assignments, which was fantastic. They helped me practice summarizing my thoughts, and helped me prepare for the exams, but they were not overbearing or busy work. My favorite part was having tea each lecture. This was one of the ways the professor encouraged us to feel relaxed and engaged.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was one of the first classes I have taken where I felt truly able to ask any question without the fear of judgement. At first, it was hard to speak up due to unfamiliarity, but after a few weeks it felt so welcoming and I learned so much by this type of class engagement. Honestly, the simple act of offering tea during class made it feel so much more relaxed and discussion based that it felt less of a requirement to participate in the course, but more of an opportunity. I also really enjoyed the question section on fridays where we went over problems that related to what we had just learned. Although hard sometimes to refrain the information that was just taught due to complexities of the topics, this was a really good opportunity to determine and understand where we might be struggling and work more on those areas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professor is very enthusiastic and easy to understand, has a very comprehensive way of giving lectures that made it very enjoyable. We loved having Nicolas as our professor!

response_text: I really enjoyed the class discussions and thought the problems that we did in lab were applicable to real world situations we might see later on in our careers.

response_text: It was stimulating for sure. I signe up for this class, (1) because I need credits, and (2) because I am genuinely interested. The foundational concepts and the different pollution issues being discussed made the class interesting and kept me learning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it. It is a wonderful class. You will learn a lot, from small, local-scale to huge global scale issues. Nicolas is an excellent and passionate teacher. And so is Perrin. Both of them made the class really interesting and fascinating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it! Even the fast pace of this course due to the shortened time was manageable due to his very thorough explanations. I’m quite frankly sad that this course is over because I felt I have learned so much and found it to be very engaging which a lot of my courses normally aren’t.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the science involved in understanding climate change as well as how it affects society at large. In particular, I learned about all of the various ways of measuring climate change, both directly through data collection implements and using proxies such as ice cores for more historic understanding. I also learned that we are 100% certain that climate change is in fact human-caused and there is no scientific proof to deny this fact. Additionally, I learned that EVs will surpass ICE demand within the next 10 years.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3. an introduction to the policy implications of climate action and inaction.

response_text: This is a good, extremely easy course for anyone who wants to learn the fundamentals of climate change. response_text: Coming into the course, be aware that it will not just be an overview of renewable energy and that class will be more technical and math-based than a humanities-based environmental science class. However, it is a really good class if you're interested in learning the science, physics, and math behind energy generation and different forms of energy. All in all, I think the class had great potential but just needed more interaction. Lastly, the class itself is not super hard, but it's important to pay close attention to lectures for the test.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout the Earth Science course, I, as a learner, developed a comprehensive understanding of various geological processes and phenomena. One of the key insights I gained pertains to the intricate interplay between Earth's internal forces and external influences, shaping the planet's dynamic features. This involved delving into the mechanics of plate tectonics, seismic activity, and volcanic processes, allowing me to appreciate the profound impact these forces have on the Earth's surface. Additionally, I honed my skills in interpreting and analyzing geological data, such as maps, cross-sections, and rock formations. This enhanced my ability to decipher the Earth's history and provided practical knowledge applicable to real-world scenarios, like identifying potential natural hazards or understanding the formation of valuable resources. Lastly, the course fostered a systems thinking approach, encouraging me to view the Earth as a complex, interconnected system where changes in one component can have cascading effects on the entire planet. This holistic perspective is invaluable for addressing contemporary environmental challenges and underscores the importance of responsible stewardship of our planet.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned a lot about the complexities of the earth system, including information on some of the geology, physics and chemistry that impact earth systems. I also learned about how scientists gather data that goes into the reports we see on earthquakes, climate change, and glacial melt.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking the Earth Science course in the future. Personally, I found it to be an incredibly enriching and eye-opening experience. This course comprehensively explores the Earth's dynamic processes, ranging from the intricate details of geological formations to the broader understanding of climatic patterns and environmental interactions. Throughout the semester, I gained a profound appreciation for the interconnectedness of Earth's systems and the impact of human activities on our planet. The engaging lectures, hands-on experiments, and field trips allowed me to apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations, enhancing my understanding of Earth's complexity. The course deepened my knowledge of natural phenomena and fostered a sense of environmental responsibility. If you are interested in understanding the world around you and the critical issues facing our planet, this Earth Science course is undoubtedly a rewarding and intellectually stimulating choice.

I've come out more informed about the topic and with the realization that we know what has to be done to help our planet - it's just that it isn't being done. You confront some really difficult things in this class, but the workload is completely manageable and is as hard as you make it to be; I genuinely think that everyone at Duke should try to take this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to identify and differentiate between a ton of tetrapods, both extant and extinct. I have a deper understanding of evolution and its mechanisms.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a lot about geology which was something completely new to me! It was cool to learn about rocks and fossils and geological processes while also learning about the evolutionary history of the planet.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the theories of the origin of life is distinct from the theory of evolution, I learned a lot about how the fossil record, despite its biases, can provide a really essential insight into evolution because there are some things that simply cannot be gathered from studying extant species (like understanding that limbs/tetrapods evolved for fully aquatic life), and I learned that evolution/the phylogenetic tree isn’t necessarily a process of progress or becoming more intelligent/advanced, because natural processes cull the tree of life, including via mass extinctions, and sexual and natural selection doesn’t necessarily privilege the smartest or ‘fittest’ per se, just those with the greatest ability to reproduce.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed learning more about the world around us and its history. I greatly enjoyed learning about geology and the trails of evidence it leaves behind.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved the content and teaching I just really think the class suffered from a general lack of engagement. I know STEM classes don’t usually make attendance required but I really think that doing so for labs AND lectures would make the class a much better environment. I would also consider having three tests instead of two because I think the first test had a little too much material covered and splitting the course into three exams instead of two may also keep students more engaged. I would also even say that if students are treating the class like a blow off and not attending, just fail them. The content is so interesting and Prof. Glass has so much to say, but having a disinterested class that barely attends, never asks questions, doesn’t participate, etc really does harm the overall learning environment. Also, I hope Prof. Glass teaches the class on macro-evolutionary trends in the fossil record in the future!! Even if just a few highly interested students take it I feel like it is still worth it! I am going abroad in the fall but if it does by chance run next spring, I would 100% take it.

response_text: Many of my recommendations for improving this class were covered in the last question, but I would recommend having lectures in this class so that students can learn from the professor the specifics of what field methods are out there in the environmental sciences, what situations/types of studies are best to use different methods in, and how to design scientific research studies. As the course was set up this semester, it felt like most of the in-class activities that were not fieldwork were a series of busy-work tasks that no one cared about completing or about hearing what others had completed.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. My favorite, and in my opinion, most important area of knowledge that I received was regarding the history of Australia, its colonization, and the existence and cultural contexts of the aboriginal peoples that were first here. To fully understand and appreciate an area, a foundation of historical analysis must be first established. I strongly enjoyed learning about many of the holistic purposes of the land, how it was affected after/during colonization, and why Australia is the way it now is. It encouraged me to consider the causes and effects of human impact. 
2. I appreciated the hands-on teaching of this course. Specifically, days in which we were able to observe marine life (such as the Bondi Beach walk, Great Barrier Reef snorkel, etc.). It allowed me to fully get a grasp on my environment 
3. I have never used a field notebook in the way I have before this class. I believe that the use of a notebook and having to actively write in it while doing activities forced me to be much more attentive and engaged. I'm also thankful I have it for future reference, as it quite literally is an accumulation of everything I did/saw/learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use a hand lens, a snorkel, and a field notebook. I got better at being an auditory learner. I learned to respect and listen to different perspectives, both of the local culture and amongst my class group. I learned how to identify species and how adaptations respond to the climate. I gained a greater understanding of how geology can shape speciation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - lots of species identifications- crossbedding!- plant strategies

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Perhaps the most valuable thing I learned during this course is to keenly observe the environment around me at all times. From spotting various unexpected plants during hikes, to thinking critically about the geological characteristics of a site, to looking out of the bus window and seeing a new animals species, I learned to always keep my eyes and ears open, even when I'm not in an allotted class activity. Secondly, I learned about basic classification for animals and plants, including Phylums and Subphylums, as well as plant reproductive strategies. Lastly, I learned how to travel and take care of myself in a foreign country by using public transport, shopping for groceries, and finding my way around unfamiliar cities. These skills will stick with me for life, far beyond the scopes of this course, and I am very excited to return to the United States feeling much more independent and knowledgeable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to identify lots of plants and animals, about the history of Australian culture and Aboriginal culture, and the geology of Australia. Both Alex Glass and Jen Glass were extremely knowledgable, being able to recall so many facts about everything that we saw (and we saw a lot). They seemed genuinely excited about the topics they were teaching, and they loved to answer all the questions we had. There was so much information that we learned through our many guides and tours, with so much information in our field notebooks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to retain information in the field- having the ability to actively take notes during a field.
2. I learned in-depth knowledge of the surrounding plants and animals
3. I learned about the perspective of aboriginal people that helped me interpret information from various points of view.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Much of the skills that I developed during the course involved gaining confidence and independence in another country. The majority of them have been assigned to finding restaurants and making meals. Throughout the program, my confidence grew and developed, and the meals were difficult to adventure through the cities alone and manage my time effectively. Another skill that I developed was studying with limited wifi. Some of the locations had minimal wifi, so it was important to be able to study effectively using my notebook, which, while a challenge at first, ended up being extremely beneficial in terms of my memorization and deeper understanding. Finally, my way of thinking about geology shifted. Being able to see geological concepts in person instead of a textbook allowed for better conceptualization and understanding. This also applied to the many organisms that we saw.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor, Dr. Alex Glass, and the TA, Jen Glass, both enthusiastically answered questions, taught us new lessons about biology, geology, and science in general, and maintained positive attitudes throughout the trip. I'm very grateful to both of them for their patience and kindness, and I think that both Alex and Jen encouraged students to be curious beyond the scope of grades and academics, which is an incredibly valuable life skill. I would definitely keep the tours led by Alex and Jen, and I think the lecture style of students writing down what the instructors say in field notebooks prepared students for real-life scientific study. Alex and Jen worked incredibly well together, and stayed calm in situations of stress and exhaustion that naturally come during a monthlong program full of activities. I especially noticed that Jen payed close attention to the mental and physical health of all students, and was always the first to offer to accompany a student to a health facility, check on students who seem to be unwell, and ensure that all students are fed, healthy, and happy. Both the instructor and the TA made this course fun, safe, and intellectually challenging, and I believe they have done a fantastic job with this program.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text:
Knowledge- pretty much everything related to how the climate operates and interacts on the Earth. Specifically:
-Periodic cycles, such as ENSO and NAO
-How and why solar radiation is difference from the long wave radiation given off by Earth, and why this matters

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The focus of this class was on teaching the theory and concepts of climate science, and helped introduce a whole new world of knowledge to us. I liked how the course was structured - each chapter focused on one aspect of the climate system (atmosphere, hydrosphere, etc) and went into a good level of depth without subjecting us to the physics and chemistry of it. Specifically, this class helped me build a good enough level of knowledge of each aspect of the climate system to a point that I can now understand the jargon and concepts - and thus broadly understand scientific papers or discussions on the subject. 
Concepts that struck me:
1. Aerosols can help reduce global warming (in some cases)! Now I finally understand the discussions on geoengineering
2. The science of coral bleaching and the importance of the ocean system in balancing our climate.
3. How complex it all actually is! I knew that it was but this course helped me understand why.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1. The five homework assignments were often quite challenging, which helped us think critically about the course content. 
2. I also really enjoyed doing the project, which gave us the opportunity to apply the scientific theory that we learnt in class to a topic of our interest. 
3. I also really really appreciated that the professor began each class by doing a recap of what we had learnt previously on that topic. This helped immensely in retaining all the dense and complex material that we were learning.
4. I liked how the professor linked many of the scientific concepts and processes of the climate system to discussions on how they would be impacted with global warming. As a climate policy researcher, these discussions were very interesting and important for me and helped me feel like the reason I took this class was fulfilled.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned many skills that apply to climate analysis, including predicting air and water parcel characteristics and interactions, wind pattern predictions, and estimating the effects of a changing climate on weather and temperature patterns more broadly. The course also covered information regarding the inner workings of air, water and carbon circulation on Earth, its natural systems, and how we are affecting them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was extremely effective in providing an overview of pollution sources in freshwater and ocean environments. I felt like the course was also effective in providing an understanding of how these pollutants interact with the environment. Not just telling us what the pollutants were, but also understanding their environmental impacts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned so much about different types of pollution and I really wish we had more time to learn more. I was really excited to learn about invasive species but the course went too fast!
2. I learned to read and think critically. Nicolas gave us enough relevant information to effectively assess the proposal of a method (e.g., deep water pumping).
3. I also actually was able to refresh some of the concepts I previously learned in limnology and stream ecology (e.g., Redfield ratio) and to learn how to determine the response of the ecosystem to changes in nutrient source.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the complexities of freshwater and ocean pollution. Many topics we discussed I had heard about generally. It was interesting getting the scientific background of each process, implementation strategies, cost analysis of implementation, and developing a critical eye for further environmental damage.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As a non-environmental major, almost everything I learned in the class was new to me! I think understanding that not all new solutions (even if proposed by renowned scholars) work and have clear fundamentals gaps, such as the deep ocean water pumping. I also found that understanding the multi-scale impacts of different pollutants very interesting, such as how one pollutant can really only affect larger species (entanglement) OR it could affect from the microbiome and work its way through biomagnification to the top of the food web. Furthermore, I found that as an engineer, we are always wanting to problem solve, but sometimes, as in the case with BP spill - the best method is to do nothing at all and that engineered solutions may exacerbate the issue (dispersants).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
I loved the learning environment that Nicolas and Perrin created. Things to keep:
1. Lecture is not always a lecture. It is something to facilitate class discussion. The fact that any student can chime in to ask question is great.
2. I loved that the class did not require a paper. It is helpful to do one, but grad classes are heavy and discussions usually serve the purpose of learning.
3. I loved that we got to present on our own interested pollution issue and invite the author to speak to the class. I have never done that before.
4. I loved that the class was small so I was comfortable speaking up.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor held the class like an open discussion, where he lectured, but at any point we could ask questions and he clarified. There were minimal HW assignments, which was fantastic. They helped me practice summarizing my thoughts, and helped me prepare for the exams, but they were not overbearing or busy work. My favorite part was having tea each lecture. This was one of the ways the professor encouraged us to feel relaxed and engaged.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was one of the first classes I have taken where I felt truly able to ask any question without the fear of judgement. At first, it was hard to speak up due to unfamiliarity, but after a few weeks it felt so welcoming and I learned so much by this type of class engagement. Honestly, the simple act of offering tea during class made it feel so much more relaxed and discussion based that it felt less of a requirement to participate in the course, but more of an opportunity. I also really enjoyed the question section on fridays where we went over problems that related to what we had just learned. Although hard sometimes to refrain the information that was just taught due to complexities of the topics, this was a really good opportunity to determine and understand where we might be struggling and work more on those areas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the science involved in understanding climate change as well as how it affects society at large. In particular, I learned about all of the various ways of measuring climate change, both directly through data collection implements and using proxies such as ice cores for more historic understanding. I also learned that we are 100% certain that climate change is in fact human-caused and there is no scientific proof to deny this fact. Additionally, I learned that EVs will surpass ICE demand within the next 10 years.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a good, extremely easy course for anyone who wants to learn the fundamentals of climate change. It is really useful for dispeling climate denialist myths, although those are becoming less important with time. If you're looking to develop climate solutions, this course won't teach you the technical or economic skills to do that. however, it is a good foundation to learn why things are the way they are. This course is about the breadth of climate change physics and policy, but not necessarily the depth of any specific tools.
